objective: How to clarify a message when it is unclear
description: You are acting as TPO Kevin. You want to enter the mainline track for inspection. Before proceeding, you must obtain permission from the Traffic Controller (TC). If the Overhead Catenary System (OCS) is still live, the TC will deny your request for safety reasons.
learning_points: Entering the track without permission is dangerous. If the Overhead Catenary System (OCS) is still live, you could be electrocuted. Always get approval from the Traffic Controller (TC) before entering.
The OCS (Overhead Catenary System) carries high-voltage electricity. If it’s live, it is not safe to enter the track.
Use the correct phrase: 'Request access to track'. This is the standard way to ask for permission. Wrong example: 'Can/May I go on the track?'

If you hear part of the message but can’t understand it, don’t guess. Asking for a repeat quickly and clearly helps avoid mistakes. Use the correct phrase: 'Difficult. Say again'. Wrong example: 'What?' or 'Sorry, I didn’t hear you'

Use catch phrases: 'negative' -- No. Wrong example: say 'No', because 'No' can sounds like other words like 'now/go'. 'Negative' is a standardized phrase recognized across all radio users. It reduces the chance of misinterpretation.
Use catch phrases: 'Wilco' -- Will comply. This is a standard phrase used to indicate agreement or readiness. Wrong example: say 'OK'
questions: Why need to request access to track?

conversation.utterance: TPO Kevin, Request access to track, over
Main Line Zero Two, Nega… (unclear), over
TPO Kevin, Difficult. Say again your last message, over
Main Line Zero Two, Negative. OCS is still live, over

questions: Why need to report a fault?
description: You are acting as TPO Sam. While on duty, you observe that Platform Screen Door (PSD) number four is malfunctioning — it is closing more slowly than normal. You must promptly report this fault to the Traffic Controller (TC) and clearly confirm their understanding of the issue.
learning_points: Faults such as a slow-closing Platform Screen Door (PSD) can affect safety and train operations. Reporting ensures the TC is aware of the issue and can take action to monitor or fix it.
Be specific about the issue — avoid vague descriptions like “there’s something wrong with the door.
When TC repeats the message back, always confirm clearly: 'Correct', Wrong example: 'Yes' or 'Right'. Those are informal and may be unclear over radio.
Confirming the message helps prevent misunderstandings. Inaccurate reports or unclear responses can lead to delays or safety issues.

Use catch phrases: 'Wilco' -- Will comply. This is a standard phrase used to indicate agreement or readiness. Wrong example: say 'OK'. Always say “Wilco” to clearly show that you understand and will follow the instruction.

conversation.utterance: TPO Sam, Platform Screen Door number four is closing slowly, over
Main Line Zero Two, Please confirm Platform Screen Door number four is closing slowly, over
TPO Sam, That is correct, over
Main Line Zero Two, Monitor for the next two trains, over

objective: Practice Read Back of critical instructions
learning_points: Always say 'Emergency, Emergency' to signal a critical situation, should say 'Emergency' twice. This immediately alerts all radio users to prioritize your message. Don’t use vague terms like 'Something is wrong' or 'There’s a problem.'

Always perform a Read Back of critical instructions. When you receive instructions during an emergency, you must Read Back the full message. This confirms that you understood the instruction exactly as given. Never just say 'OK' or 'Got it' — it’s not clear or complete.
'Roger' means 'Message received and understood.' It does not mean that action is required — it simply acknowledges the message.

'Wait out' means: I have received your message and will respond later. It tells you to stay off the radio and wait for further contact. This is used when the controller needs time to gather more information or give further orders.
description: You are the Train Operator of Car 09, currently driving along the depot track. While approaching Track Sierra One East, you observe a serious rail crack near Point 833. This is an emergency situation and must be reported immediately.
